contexto: Main high-capacity road used to move traffic across a city.
High-speed roadway, sometimes requiring a toll.
High-speed roadway with no tolls.
General urban road for local traffic.

destino_term: Calle Cerrada con Retorno; Fondo de Saco
contexto: Dead-end street that allows vehicles to turn around.
Road with no exit or continuation.
Road that gathers traffic from local streets and feeds larger roads.
Low-speed street providing direct access to homes or businesses.
Street where traffic moves in only one direction.

destino_term: Calle de Sentido Único Reversible, o Alterno
contexto: Street whose direction changes based on time or demand.
Street where one direction has priority over the opposite.
General road, often rural or secondary.

origen_term: Subsidiary road; formerly Farm to market road
contexto: Road connecting rural areas to nearby towns or markets.
Short-distance secondary road.
Major intercity road for long-distance travel.
Highway that connects two or more countries.
Main road managed at the national level.
Road serving travel within a specific region.
Lower-priority highway compared to major routes.
Main backbone route within a road network.
Lane used to adjust speed before merging or exiting.
Lane where vehicles gain speed before merging.
Lane where vehicles slow down before exiting.
Lane used to temporarily store vehicles before movement.
Lane whose direction changes during peak hours.

destino_term: Carril de Subida; Carril de ascenso
contexto: Extra lane for slower vehicles on steep grades.
Road element that distributes traffic to different routes.
Internal circulation aisle, often in parking areas.
Sloped connection between roads or levels.
Section of a highway passing through a town.
General term for a public road or route.
Limited-access high-speed roadway.
Track system used for trains.
Parallel road giving access to properties along a highway.
Scenic road often surrounded by green areas.
Road where one traffic stream has priority.
Designated area for vehicles to wait temporarily.
